Description: an informal fallacy wherein a conclusion is drawn about all or many instances of a phenomenon on the basis of one or a few instances of that phenomenon. is an example of jumping to conclusions.
Logical Form: Sample S is taken from population P. Sample S is a very small part of population P. Conclusion C is drawn from sample S and applied to population P.
Masked Logical Form: <MSK1> is taken from <MSK2>. <MSK1> is a very small part of <MSK2>. <MSK3> is drawn from <MSK2> and applied to <MSK1>.

Description: statement that jumps to a conclusion implying a causal relationship without supporting evidence
Logical Form:
A occurred, then B occurred.
Therefore, A caused B.

Description: when the end of an argument comes back to the beginning without having proven itself.
Logical Form:
X is true because of Y.

Y is true because of X.
Masked Logical Form:
<MSK1> is true because of <MSK2>.

<MSK2> is true because of <MSK1>.

Description: a fallacious argument which is based on affirming that something is real or better because the majority thinks so
Logical Form: A lot of people believe X.Therefore, X must be true.
Masked Logical Form: A lot of people believe <MSK1>.Therefore, <MSK1> must be true.

Description: instead of addressing someone's argument or position, you irrelevantly attack the person or some aspect of the person who is making the argument.
Logical Form:
Person 1 is claiming Y.

Person 1 is a moron.

Therefore, Y is not true.
Masked Logical Form:
<MSK1> is claiming <MSK2>.

<MSK1> is a moron.

Therefore, <MSK2> is not true.

Description: an error in the logical structure of an argument.
Logical Form: If A is true, then B is true. B is true. Therefore, A is true.
Masked Logical Form: If <MSK1> is true, then <MSK2> is true.<MSK2> is true. Therefore, <MSK1> is true.

Description: manipulation of the recipient's emotions in order to win an argument
Logical Form: Claim X is made without evidence. In place of evidence, emotion is used to convince the interlocutor that X is true.
Masked Logical Form: <MSK1> is made without evidence. In place of evidence, emotion is used to convince the interlocutor that <MSK1> is true.

Description: presenting only two options or sides when there are many options or sides.
Logical Form: Either X or Y is true.

Description: when a key term or phrase in an argument is used in an ambiguous way, with one meaning in one portion of the argument and then another meaning in another portion of the argument.
Logical Form:
Term X is used to mean Y in the premise.
Term X is used to mean Z in the conclusion.
Masked Logical Form:
<MSK1> is used to mean <MSK2> in the premise.
<MSK1> is used to mean <MSK3> in the conclusion.

Description: attacking an exaggerated or caricatured version of your opponent's position.
Logical Form: Person 1 makes claim Y. Person 2 restates person 1â€™s claim (in a distorted way). Person 2 attacks the distorted version of the claim. Therefore, claim Y is false.
Masked Logical Form: <MSK1> makes claim <MSK2>. <MSK3> restates <MSK2> (in a distorted way). <MSK3> attacks the distorted version of the claim. Therefore, <MSK2> is false.

Description: introducing premises or conclusions that have nothing to do with the subject matter.
Logical Form: It is claimed that X implies Y, whereas X is unrelated to Y
Masked Logical Form: It is claimed that <MSK1> implies <MSK2>, whereas <MSK1> is unrelated to <MSK2>

Understandable Name: attacking the character of the speaker
Description: attempts to disprove an argument by attacking the character of the speaker.
Logical Form: Person 1 makes claim Y. Person 2 claims Person 1 is not a credible source regarding claim Y. Therefore, Y is false
Masked Logical Form: <MSK1> makes <MSK2>. <MSK3> claims <MSK1> is not a credible source regarding <MSK2>. Therefore, Y is false

Description: some intentional (sometimes subconscious) action/choice to incorrectly support an argument
Logical Form: Person 1 knows claim X is incorrect. They still claim that X is correct using an incorrect argument
Masked Logical Form: <MSK1> knows <MSK2> is incorrect. They still claim that <MSK1> is correct using an incorrect argument
